interactions.content:
{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': '5f04r56vmb', 'content': 'In a chemistry class, you may have learned that the strength of an acid
is determined by the stability of its conjugate base. In other words, the
pKa of an acid is lower—favoring dissociation into H+ and A- if A- is
relatively stable as an anion. Using the concept of electrostatic
potential energy, how can this conception of the strength of acids be
used to rationalize the increase in acidity as one goes down the
halides from top to bottom: F, Cl, Br, and I?'}
{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': '5f04r56vmb', 'content': 'Which part of the van der Waals interaction depends on temperature?\nWhy?'}

{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': '5f04r56vmb', 'content': 'The Boltzmann constant times the temperature, kT, is often used as
a measure of energy, called the thermal energy. The strength of a
van der Waals bond of two small uncharged molecules is around
1kT, for water—which exhibits strong hydrogen bonding—the
strength of the interaction is around 10kT. What is the value of the
thermal energy at room temperature (298 K)? What is the approximate
(order of magnitude) value of the strength of an ionic bond as
in NaCl?'}
{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': '5f04r56vmb', 'content': 'Explain why butane (C4H10) is a gas at room temperature while octadecane\n(C18H38) is a solid.'}

{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': '5f04r56vmb', 'content': 'The situation depicted at the bottom of Figure 2.1 seems to suggest that particles always spread out in a closed system due to entropy. That is, physical systems tend to move toward configurations which maximize the number of available statistical microstates. In light of this tendency, why do oil and water separate in salad dressing? What other forces do we have to consider?'}

{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': '5f04r56vmb', 'content': 'Imagine two particles that interact with a negative potential energy at
a given distance of separation, r. Is the force attractive or repulsive?
What information do you need to know about the interaction to be
certain?'}

{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': '5f04r56vmb', 'content': 'Calculate the van der Waals coefficient C$_{VDW}$ for two neon atoms interacting in a vacuum. You may assume the orbital frequency $\\nu$ is 5.5$\\times$10$^{15}$ Hz and the polarizability divided by the usual constants $\\alpha_{0}/(4\\pi\\epsilon_{0})=0.39\\times10^{-30}$ m$^3$. Then use this value to calculate the strength of the van der Waals bond at contact if the van der Waals radius for neon is 0.154 nm.'}

{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': '5f04r56vmb', 'content': 'Recall the van der Waals equation of state from chemistry: it is the equation that makes corrections to the idea gas equation for attractive forces ($a$ parameter) and excluded volume ($b$ parameter). In light of what you learned in this chapter, how would you expect the $a$ and $b$ parameters of the Van der Waals equation of state to differ between iodine (I\\_{2}) and chlorine (Cl\\_{2}) gas?'}

{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': '5f04r56vmb', 'content': 'There is a van der Waal interaction between two atoms 5 nm apart that can be modeled using a Lennard-Jones potential, with $A=10^{-76}$ J m$^6$ and $B=10^{-135}$ J m$^{12}$. Calculate the force.'}

{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': '5f04r56vmb', 'content': 'Calculate the separation *r* in nanometers beyond which the interaction\nenergy between a barium ion and a bromide ion falls below *kT* at room\ntemperature in a vacuum.'}
